EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.0    FACILITY OVERVIEW AND SOURCE DESCRIPTION
Holloman Air Force Base (HAFB) is located in south-central New Mexico, 
in Otero County, and is adjacent to the City of Alamogordo.  The base is 
owned and operated by the United States Air Force Air Combat 
Command and is home for the 49th Fighter Wing.  The size of HAFB, 
combined with its primary combat support mission and presence of base 
housing for permanent party and temporary duty personnel, requires that 
the base provide services and support an infrastructure similar to those 
that may exist in a medium-size, non-military municipality.
The base operates a wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) for treating 
wastewater produced on-site.  The WWTP uses a mixture of chlorine gas 
dissolved in water for chlorinating plant effluent, influent, and an 
activated sludge stream.  Chlorine, required to perform the chlorination 
tasks, is received and dispensed from standard one-ton chlorine 
containers that meet or exceed the U.S. Department of Transportation 
specifications for design and testing.  The inventory of chlorine exceeds 
the threshold of 2,500 pounds, specified in the Risk Management Program 
regulation, and therefore, triggers the submission of a Risk Management 
Plan (RMP) at least every five years.  This submission represents the second 
update or revision, of the original RMP that was prepared and submitted 
June 1999.
2.0    HAZARD ASSESSMENT
A hazard assessment was performed to determine the endpoint distances 
that may result from a worst-case and alternative-case (i.e., more likely) 
accidental release of chlorine from a one-ton container and the human and 
environmental receptors within the impact area.  The results of the hazard 
assessment are included in attachments to this Executive Summary.  
Endpoint distances were determined by applying the Environmental 
Protection Agency's recommended approach that is contained in their 
most current guidance document entitled Risk Management Prog

ram 
Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants, dated May 2000.
3.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION
The WWTP's chlorine release prevention program consists of compliance 
with the following elements of  the Occupational Safety and Health 
Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly 
Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR 1910.119) standard: 

?    Employee participation;
?    Process safety information;
?    Process hazard analyses;
?    Operating procedures;
?    Training;
?    Contractors;
?    Mechanical integrity;
?    Management of change;
?    Pre-startup safety review;
?    Incident investigation;
?    Hot work permit;
?    Emergency response program; and
?    Compliance audits.
The major objective of this prevention program is to implement a  
management system that prevents releases of chlorine, especially into 
locations that could expose employees and others to serious hazards.  The 
program employs a systematic approach to evaluating the whole process 
including process design, process technology, process changes, 
operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine 
activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans and procedures, 
training programs, and other interrelated elements that effect the WWTP 
chlorine system.
The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design 
and operation of the WWTP system to prevent or mitigate a chlorine 
release are evaluated and strengthened through the prevention program 
to ensure their effectiveness.  The prevention program proactively 
identifies, evaluates, and mitigates chlorine releases that could occur as a 
result of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment. Some of the key 
components of the prevention program are summarized below:
?    The development, documentation, and operator availability of 
critical process safety information regarding the hazards of chlorine 
and the design of the system and equipment.  This information is 
used to fully understand and safely operate the chlorine system.

?    The development and execution of an employee participation 
program for WWTP employees.  This program assures that 
employees that operate the chlorine system and are most 
knowledgeable about it are able to easily, effectively, and regularly 
recommend changes or improvements which enhance safety.
?    The performance of a formal initial PHA on the chlorine system 
using the hazard and operability (HAZOP) study technique, and  
revalidation PHAs, that occurred in November 2003(Note: The PHA was actually finalized in February 2004) and January 2009, which also 
employed the HAZOP study technique.  A team with expertise in 
engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the 
existing system in depth and developed recommendations to 
improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHAs 
addressed:  (1) process hazards, (2) previous incidents, 
(3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the 
hazards, (4) the consequence of control failure, (5) facility siting, 
(6) human factors, and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety 
and health effects of control system failures.  The PHA will be 
updated and revalidated every five years.
?    Written operating procedures (OPs) are used to provide the basis 
for proper and safe operation of the chlorine system.  The OPs 
include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, 
emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  They also 
describe safe operating limits for temperature and pressure, the 
consequences of operating outside these safe operating limits, and a 
description of safety systems and how they operate.
?    Formal authorization systems (i.e., management of change 
procedure, pre-startup safety review) are in place to ensure that 
system changes or expansions are as safe as the original design and 
that an independent recheck confirms that the changes are 
consistent with the engineering design and in a condition to be 
safely operated prior to startup.
?    Events that might

(or did) cause an accidental or unexpected 
release of chlorine are subjected to a formal investigation.  The 
objective of the investigation is to correct deficiencies in such a way 
as to prevent recurrence.
?    Contractors that are hired to work on, or adjacent to, the chlorine 
system are "pre-qualified" based on their demonstrated ability to 
work safely.  

?    Prior to the performance of any hot work (i.e., spark or flame 
producing operations such as welding, cutting, brazing, grinding), 
management must approve the work by executing a written hot 
work authorization permit to verify that appropriate precautions to 
prevent fire have been implemented.
?    Periodic formal walk-throughs occur to find unusual conditions, 
incipient leaks, or other indications of potential upsets or failures 
that could lead to a release.
?    Utilization of safety systems, including emergency exhaust; 
absorption scrubber; automated container valve(s); room sensors 
interlocked to the emergency exhaust system and scrubber; and 
audible and visual alarms.  Monthly operation and inspection of 
the entire scrubber system, including interlocks.
?    Regular inspection of switches and shutdown devices that have 
safety implications.
?    Periodic inspection of major powered equipment, including fans, 
pumps, bearings, couplings, shaft seals, mountings, etc., for 
vibration or incipient mechanical failure.
?    Proper system design, including adherence to recognized safety 
codes (i.e., The Chlorine Institute standards and guidance).
4.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The HAFB WWTP has prepared and executed an emergency action plan 
(EAP) that satisfies the OSHA standard Employee Emergency Plans and Fire 
Prevention Plans, found at 29 CFR 1910.38.  The EAP covers the designated 
actions that must be taken to assure employee safety from fire, small 
releases of chlorine, and other emergency conditions.  The HAFB also has a 
full time (24 hours per day; 7 days per week) professional hazardous 
material resp

onse team that is properly trained and equipped and capable 
of responding to the WWTP within five minutes in order to plug, patch, or 
otherwise stop a chlorine release.  Specific hazardous material procedures 
and practices are contained in the following facility documents.
?    Disaster Preparedness Readiness Plan 32-1; and
?    WWTP Pre-Fire Plan (Air Force Document 1028).
There is also a mutual aid relationship between HAFB and the City of 
Alamogordo and HAFB is represented on the Otero County Local 
Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).
5.0    ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of chlorine at the facility in the last 
five years that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property 
damage on-site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, 
property damage, or environmental damage.
6.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The prevention program that is described in Section 3.0 of this Executive 
Summary is a management system that is designed to proactively identify, 
evaluate, and reduce the potential for a chlorine release and/or a release's 
impact or consequence, due to failures in process, procedures, and 
equipment.  As safety improvements are identified by the management 
system they are evaluated and, where appropriate , implemented.  For 
example, the facility is currently in the process of resolving the specific 
recommendations that resulted from the comprehensive process hazard 
analysis revalidation that occurred in January 2009.
